reasoning_trace.value: The paper includes several figures and charts that illustrate the system architecture, experimental setup, and performance results. Figure 1 shows the concept of photonic-based THz ISAC for fiber-wireless networks. Figure 2 displays the experimental setup of the photonic-based D-band sub-THz ISAC system. Figures 3-10 show various performance metrics, such as BER, SNR, and range resolution.

reasoning_trace.description: Explain the System Mechanism and ISAC Coupling Mode found.
reasoning_trace.value: The system uses a photonic-based THz ISAC architecture, where communication and radar sensing functions are achieved through time-division multiplexing (TDM) of 16-QAM and LFM signals. The ISAC signal is generated in the central unit (CU) and transmitted to the active antenna unit (AAU) via a long-distance single-mode fiber (SMF). The AAU uses a thin-film lithium niobate Mach-Zehnder modulator (TFLN-MZM) for full-photonic direct reception and de-chirping of the THz LFM echo signal.

reasoning_trace.description: Validate the physical consistency of reported metrics (Rate/Resolution).
reasoning_trace.value: The paper reports a range resolution of 6 mm and a peak data rate of 116 Gbit/s. The reported metrics are physically consistent with the system architecture and experimental setup. The use of a TFLN-MZM for full-photonic direct reception and de-chirping of the THz LFM echo signal enables high-resolution radar sensing and high-speed communication.

reasoning_trace.description: Identify the solved problems and remaining open challenges.
reasoning_trace.value: The paper solves the problem of achieving high-resolution radar sensing and high-speed communication in a photonic-based THz ISAC system. However, the system still faces challenges such as false target suppression, range ambiguity, and system complexity. Future research directions include exploring new waveforms, improving system robustness, and demonstrating the system's feasibility in practical scenarios.
